item.title: Dokkodo Measure
item.description: Miyamoto Musashi wrote the Dokkōdō. The Dokkodo Measure is a number telling you how “on the path” you will be.

item.title: Knowing Yourself
item.description: Context I watched a YouTube video about Destiny interviewing Dr. K. Near the end, Destiny asks Alok: what is the number one tip he would give to someone who wants to be more mentally healthy. The tip is to know yourself. Quoting Alok: Understand yourself in the same way your try to understand external things. I hadn’t really thought about it this way. The way I try to understand anything externally is through the scientific method (usually).

item.title: Cat in Car
item.description: Many dog walkers have passed by my car. Those who listened closely heard a faint meow. That’s because there was a little kitten inside the engine bay. I decided to go grocery shopping one Saturday morning. When I sat down at the steering wheel, I saw a paper note slid beneath the wind shield wiper. I read a sloppy cursive that said a kitten was in my car. At first, I was confused.

item.title: Brother Left
item.description: Honesty My brother crashed at my place for two to three months to finish an internship in Austin. Today, he left. On the way back home, from the airport, I could feel what every writer describes as the precursor to crying. Part of it is the throat swelling. Part of it is the eye closing. I want to understand myself more, so I tried my best to be honest. I didn’t try to put on a tough act.

item.title: Meta Nihilism
item.description: I’ve been thinking about the meaningless of everything. The universe is inherently pointless. I think philosophers like to call it nihilism. I’ve heard people say that although it is a depressing thought, it is actually very uplifting. The main idea is that you get to create the meaning to your life. This is as liberating as it gets. I read some Reddit comment a while back. I’m paraphrasing here: The next logical leap is to ask what nihilism says about nihilism.
